title: Mohammad Sayeef Alam
text:
I am a doctoral candidate at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology in Trondheim, with a strong background in health data analysis. My research focuses on statistical genetics and gastrointestinal diseases, where I work with tools like R, Python, and Bash.
In my spare time, I enjoy creating visualizations and building interactive applications to support decision-making in healthcare, and I’m driven by the chance to use programming to address challenges in healthcare using real-world data.

title: MSA
text:
I’m a doctoral candidate at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU) in Trondheim, where my research focuses on statistical genetics and gastrointestinal diseases. With a strong foundation in statistics and biostatistics, I work with real-world health data to support better decision-making in healthcare.
My work involves applying advanced statistical methods and programming in R, Python, and bash. I also enjoy building interactive tools—such as Shiny apps—that help make complex data more accessible and actionable. I’m especially motivated by the opportunity to use programming to address real-world challenges in healthcare.
What motivates me most is the opportunity to apply programming and analytics to real-world challenges in healthcare. I find it rewarding to contribute to projects that have practical impact, whether through research, collaboration, or tool development.
Beyond research, I value community and connection. During the month of Ramadan, I volunteer at the MSiT mosque in Trondheim, helping serve food to people of all faiths—whether they are breaking their fast or simply sharing a warm meal with friends. It’s a small way to contribute to a welcoming and inclusive environment.
Outside of work, I enjoy hiking, swimming, improving my Norwegian and cooking for others. These activities help me stay grounded and bring balance to my academic life. I’m always eager to learn, collaborate, and contribute to projects that make a meaningful impact.



See ya later ⛷️

title: Mohammad Sayeef Alam
text:
Associate, Parexel – Remote, India
July 2021 – February 2022

Developed interactive platforms (e.g., RShiny) for economic evaluations.
Performed statistical analyses aligned with HTA guidelines across multiple disease areas.
Automated dashboards (Excel/VBA) for clinical endpoint visualization.
Coordinated projects and managed client expectations.
Contributed to SAPs and validated datasets.
Presented analytical results to stakeholders and refined deliverables.

title: Mohammad Sayeef Alam
text:
PhD, NTNU – Trondheim, Norway
April 2022 – Current

Applied advanced statistical methods to genetic and registry data.
Designed analysis pipelines to improve efficiency.
Presented findings at conferences and published in peer-reviewed journals.
Collaborated with external research groups.
Built academic networks and secured over 150,000 NOK in funding.

title: Mohammad Sayeef Alam
text:
Nordic Shortfall Calculator

Developed a model to calculate shortfall for Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden.
Provides estimates of QALE based on EQ-5D/3D values.
Includes comparative options, discount rates, and dynamic inputs.

title: Mohammad Sayeef Alam
text:
The GBIF Data Explorer is a web application that allows users to explore and analyze biodiversity data for Poland from the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF) database.
The app is built using the Shiny package for R. It includes several visualizations and filters created using the following packages: DT, shiny, shinyWidgets, shinythemes, shinyjs, bslib, bsicons, lubridate, leaflet, highcharter…. Check out the shiny dashboard

title: Mohammad Sayeef Alam
section: Collaborating between Python and R using Reticulate
text:
Collaborating between Python and R using Reticulate






Both R and Python are powerful data science languages and can be used to accomplish end-to-end analytics projects. Reticulate makes it easy to collaborate and talk between the two languages. I think of it as a translator on my fingertips.
My teammate and I participated in Microsoft hackathon where we accessed data from APIs using Python, pulled the output in R using Reticulate and created visualizations to derive business insights using Ggplot2… Check out how

title: Mohammad Sayeef Alam
section: Data visualizations - Animation and Interactivity using Gganimate and Plotly
text:
Data visualizations - Animation and Interactivity using Gganimate and Plotly


Animation brings in a key component of analysis where the third parameter you want to animate is not directly visible in your plot. Sometimes it can tell a powerful story and sometimes it can just add some flair to an otherwise low-key story.
This blog goes through examples and code to show how easy it is to use gganimate and plotly packages to animate your data visualizations and make them interactive…. Continue reading

title: Mohammad Sayeef Alam
section: Sales forecasting and anomaly detection Shiny dashboard
text:
Sales forecasting and anomaly detection Shiny dashboard






This dashboard, built with Shiny Flex capability, looks at data from EverythingYouWillNeed.com website (fake data) to report out odaily product sales. You can select the product, the dates to analyze and click on apply to replicate the report, check sales forecast and anomalies for the specific product choice.
Giving your stakeholders the ability to play with product grain forecast and anomaly detection is a great was to get them on-board prior to deploying any model at scale. This Shiny dashboard was built specifically for that purpose…. Link to play with the Shiny dashboard

title: MSA
text:
The Nordic Shortfall Calculator is a web application that allows users to explore and analyze the QALY shortfall based on updated utility values as well as compare them to previous values or even values used by other Nordic countries.
The app is built using the Shiny package for R. It includes several visualizations and filters created using the following packages: DT, shiny, shinyWidgets, shinythemes, shinyjs, bslib, bsicons, lubridate, leaflet, highcharter…. Check out the shiny app

title: MSA
text:
Both R and Excel are powerful data science tools and can be used to accomplish end-to-end analytics projects.
Gudrun and I, are trying to move the decision analytics model built on excel to R, to promote open-access science. The decision analytics model runs a Markov model to assess the cost effectiveness of intervention for obesity.

title: Learnings from first R package development
text: This documentation is for individuals such as me, to create more than basic R package while debugging common errors, warnings and notes.

title: Git and SSH Setup Guide
text:
Introduction
This guide provides step-by-step instructions to:

Connect your Git account
Set up SSH keys
Create a local Git repository
Link it to an online repository



Step 1: Connect Git Account

Hoping that you have git downloaded and installed if not you can download from official website
Configure your Git identity:

git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com"


Step 2: Set Up SSH Keys

Generate SSH key:

ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your.email@example.com"
Press Enter to accept the default file location.

Start the SSH agent:

eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"

Add your SSH key to the agent:

ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

Copy the SSH key to your clipboard:

cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

Add the key to your Git hosting service (e.g., GitHub, GitLab) under Settings > SSH > Add new key.



Step 3: Create Local Git Repository
Navigate to your project directory:
cd /path/to/your/project
Initialize Git:
git init
Add files and commit:
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"


Step 4: Link to Online Repository
Create a new repository on GitHub/GitLab (without README if already committed locally).
Link your local repo:
git remote add origin git@github.com:yourusername/your-repo.git
Sometimes it maybe master or main. You can check that by
git branch
Push your code:
git push -u origin master
Here the -u parameter means upstream so next time you can just write git push and it will remember that you wish to push it to master. (useful when you have single branch)
After this you only need to repeat the following:
git add .
git commit -m "provide new commit comment"
git push origin master

title: QALY Shortfall calculator for Nordics
text:
The Nordic Shortfall Calculator is a web application that allows users to explore and analyze the QALY shortfall based on updated utility values as well as compare them to previous values or even values used by other Nordic countries.
The app is built using the Shiny package for R. It includes several visualizations and filters created using the following packages: DT, shiny, shinyWidgets, shinythemes, shinyjs, bslib, bsicons, lubridate, leaflet, highcharter…. Check out the shiny app

title: Packaging MOON in R
text:
Both R and Excel are powerful data science tools and can be used to accomplish end-to-end analytics projects.
Gudrun and I, are trying to move the decision analytics model built on excel to R, to promote open-access science. The decision analytics model runs a Markov model to assess the cost effectiveness of intervention for obesity.
